quiz.title: Grade 12 Advanced Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5, Quiz 7: Applications of Electromagnetic Induction
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A flat circular loop of radius 0.10 m is rotating in a uniform magnetic field of 0.20 T. What is the maximum flux ($\Phi$) through the loop?
questions.explanation: Maximum flux occurs when the loop's plane is perpendicular to $\vec{B}$: $\Phi_{max} = BA = B(\pi r^2) = 0.20 \times \pi \times (0.10)^2 = 0.20 \times 0.0314 \approx 0.00628\text{ Wb}$.

questions.question: A magnet is dropped through a copper pipe. It falls slower than a non-magnetic object because:
options: The air resistance is higher for magnets.
Induced eddy currents create a magnetic field that opposes the motion.
Copper is a ferromagnetic material that sticks to the magnet.
The magnet becomes heavier as it falls.
questions.explanation: As the magnet falls, its changing magnetic field induces eddy currents in the conducting pipe. By Lenz's Law, these currents create magnetic fields that oppose the magnet's motion, causing magnetic damping.

questions.question: A square loop (10 cm × 10 cm) is pulled out of a 0.5 T field at a constant speed of 2.0 m/s. If the loop resistance is 0.2 Ω, the induced current is:
questions.explanation: Motional EMF: $\varepsilon = BLv = 0.5 \times 0.1 \times 2.0 = 0.1\text{ V}$ (L = 0.1 m, one side length). Current: $I = \varepsilon/R = 0.1/0.2 = 0.5\text{ A}$.

questions.question: According to the formula $\varepsilon = -N \frac{\Delta\Phi}{\Delta t}$, what happens to the EMF if the time interval for the flux change is cut in half?
questions.explanation: Since $\varepsilon \propto 1/\Delta t$ (for constant $\Delta\Phi$), halving $\Delta t$ doubles the EMF. This shows faster flux changes produce larger induced voltages.

questions.question: A loop of wire is moving into a magnetic field directed into the page. What is the direction of the induced current?
options: Toward the center of the field
questions.explanation: As the loop enters, flux into the page increases. By Lenz's Law, the induced current creates a field out of the page to oppose this increase. Using right-hand rule for loops: field out of page requires counter-clockwise current.

questions.question: Which of the following would result in a "back-EMF" in an electric motor?
options: The rotation of the armature in the magnetic field.
questions.explanation: As a motor spins, its coils cut magnetic field lines, generating an induced EMF opposite to the applied voltage (back-EMF). This is why motors draw less current as they speed up.

questions.question: A transformer works on the principle of:
questions.explanation: Transformers use mutual induction: a changing current in the primary coil creates changing flux in the core, which induces a voltage in the secondary coil via Faraday's Law.

questions.question: If the magnetic field $B$ through a loop is constant, but the area $A$ of the loop is shrinking at a rate of 0.05 m²/s, is an EMF induced?
options: Yes, because the flux $\Phi = BA$ is changing.
No, because area is a scalar.
Yes, but only if the wire is iron.
questions.explanation: Flux $\Phi = BA$. Even with constant $B$, if $A$ changes, $\Phi$ changes, inducing an EMF. Rate of change: $d\Phi/dt = B(dA/dt)$.

questions.question: A bar magnet is held vertically and dropped through a horizontal loop of wire. As the magnet leaves the loop (South pole pointing up), the induced current direction is:
options: The same as when it entered.
questions.explanation: When entering (North pole down), flux downward increases → induced current creates upward field (CCW from above). When leaving (South pole up), flux downward decreases → induced current creates downward field (CW from above). Directions are opposite.

questions.question: The peak EMF produced by an AC generator is 120 V. If the rotation speed of the coil is doubled, the new peak EMF will be:
questions.explanation: Peak EMF $\varepsilon_{max} = NBA\omega$, where $\omega$ is angular speed. Doubling $\omega$ doubles $\varepsilon_{max}$: $\varepsilon_{max}' = NBA(2\omega) = 2\varepsilon_{max} = 240\text{ V}$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered applied electromagnetic induction, including motional EMF, magnetic damping, transformers, and generator principles.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of induction applications. Review the relationship between rotation speed and generator output, and practice analyzing direction changes in dynamic scenarios.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Calculating flux and motional EMF, 2) Applying Lenz's Law to moving objects, 3) Understanding how generators and transformers work, 4) Analyzing direction changes during complete motion cycles.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review Faraday's Law and Lenz's Law, practice calculating induced EMF from changing area/field, and understand the physical principles behind common electromagnetic devices.
